item.title: NYTimes.com: Atheists, Work With Us for Peace, Pope Says on Christmas
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
NYTimes.com: Atheists, Work With Us for Peace, Pope Says on Christmas

Pope Francis, celebrating his first Christmas as Roman Catholic leader, on Wednesday called on atheists to unite with believers of all religions and work for "a homemade peace" that can spread across the world. Continue reading.

item.title: Most important next step is to get the...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Most important next step is to get the vision down to paper.

item.title: Can Do vs Can't Do Culture
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
http://recode.net/2014/01/01/can-do-vs-cant-do-culture/
Read the article in full!

item.title: On the Shoulders of Giants
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Wikipedia has proved that the community can provide content. (1970 full-text volumes of it).
WordPress has proved that the community can build a powerful web platform. 2million lines of it.
Reddit has proved that the community can curate the most interesting news. (1748386638 votes later)
Kickstarter has proved that financial support is out there while a project is still getting off the ground.
BugZilla has proved that a damn good open-source "issue tracker" can be made. But it's not accessible for the layman.
We need more than news. We need more than objectivity. We need more than a blogging platform. We need BugZilla for the real world.

item.title: Upset Sentiments
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Many of the conversations I have over dinner find themselves taking on a serious tone. Everyone has an opinion about Our Problems.
We talk about community or political issues that upset us, but then what? A lot of the energy spent ranting among friends and family seems to disappear into the aether.
I think there is another option. We can contribute to a space that grows over time to make a difference, instead of blowing over with the next news cycle. That's our goal for MTM.

item.title: New Forums
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: There's now a discussion forum to talk about MTM with everyone. You can access it by clicking "Discussion" in the Nav menu or by visiting: www.maybethismatters.org/forums Keep on rockin

item.title: Introducing MTM
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: After trying to introduce MTM too many times, it became easier to make this document: maybethismatters.org/intro.pdf

item.title: MTM Across the Web
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
You're reading something on the internet:
  • demonstrators are killed in Ukraine
  • students are shot in Venezuela
  • children are gassed in Syria
That's fucked up. You're pissed. Frustrated. Sad. You want to do something. What can you do? This shouldn't stand. Why isn't anyone doing anything about this? You come to a bit of text in blue: civilians are being killed in the streets. It's a link to a website maybethismatters.org. Trailing the end of the link is a rectangle graphic inline with the text. It has a picture of our planet, the text "This Matters", and then a number. What is this number? It looks like a score. Reminds you of a Facebook Like. It says 1,280. That's a lot. 1200 what? What does this mean? Does that mean that 1,280 people Liked this issue? These scumbags "Like" the fact that people are dying? But wait. That's not what it says. The rectangle said "This Matters". It sounds more serious. Is this more important than just a "Like"? What does "This Matters" mean? Is it going to last longer than a Facebook news feed?

item.title: Why the "Why?"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Why does this matter?

The Why does this matter? section is the first listed on Issue pages because this section is so important. Think of the great line by Antoine de Saint Exupery, or Simon Sinek's "Start with Why" speech. If you post an issue but it fails to garner much support or endorsement, your best bet is to strengthen the Why does this matter? section.

item.title: David Brin: "Proxy Activism"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
In 2005, best-selling science fiction author David Brin wrote a fantastic article about the power of collective action to improve the world.
[include excerpts]
Read it in full on his website: http://www.davidbrin.com/proxyactivism.html
Thanks, Warren :)

item.title: "The Disconnected, Connected World"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
http://www.disconnectedworld.com/ted1transcript/
Larry Kresslin has delivered a TEDTalk on some of the challenges we face as a community. He makes a strong case that we stand disconnected, despite more connectivity technology than ever. He talks about the lack of shared purpose.
At MTM we believe this has to do with a disconnect in intention. How can we connect around common goals and purpose.

item.title: "Exit, Voice, and Loyalty"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Are you familiar with "Exit, Voice, and Loyalty" by economist Albert Hirschman? In his framework, MTM makes it easier for the individual to voice. So that you can improve your community without being forced to leave it.

item.title: Goals from February
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Just some goal-setting that could be interesting to follow: A single issue gets 10 endorsements User can create their own account 3 users upload their own pictures for their accounts
1/3 so far.
Users can submit issues themselves Another moderator joins the team 100 issues submitted An issue is resolved thanks to MTM Another developer submits a pull request A news publication writes about MTM World Peace

item.title: new MTM Facebook page
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: MTM now has its own Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/maybethismatters

item.title: "Catherine Bracy: Why good hackers make good citizens"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Hacking is about more than mischief-making or political subversion. As Catherine Bracy describes in this spirited talk, it can be just as much a force for good as it is for evil. She spins through some inspiring civically-minded projects in Honolulu, Oakland and Mexico City — and makes a compelling case that we all have what it takes to get involved.
Original post Thanks for sharing, Kenny

item.title: Clayton Christianson on Open Innovation
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: http://www.claytonchristensen.com/open-innovation/ Clayton Christianson, Havard Business School professor, author of seminal work The Innovator's Dilemma Writes on open innovation and collaboration

item.title: "How to Make the World a Better Place"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Was reading this great book: http://www.amazon.com/How-Make-World-Better-Place/dp/0393312917
It would be wonderful if Mr. Hollander would feel comfortable including some of his tips in MTM.
Especially opening chapter common responses to resistance.

item.title: How to Tackle an Awareness Problem
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
How to Tackle an Awareness Problem
We can send you reminders to share the issue with a new person.
Including a special link for analytics? I can install that open-source URL shortener.
Need to go through a real world example.
What issue has awareness problem? How can they use MTM to tackle that?

item.title: MTM is A place for you to fix...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
MTM is: A place for you to fix the issues that you care most about A place to learn what you can do to make the world better A place to build a community around other people that care
  1. be heard about the issues you care most about = Speech
  2. connect with others that care about fixing similar issues = Community
  3. learn specific things you can do to make the world better = Action

item.title: Democracy is how you make the state ethical...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Democracy is how you make the state ethical.
The more people involved, the better the outcome. The less people involved, the more opportunist the state of affairs.
Infuse good into the State

item.title: What does the World Peace Project mean to you?
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: What does the World Peace Project mean to you? What is your vision? What are you interested in creating?

item.title: If you want to build a ship don't...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
If you want to build a ship, don't drum up people to collect wood and don't assign them tasks and work, but rather teach them to long for the endless immensity of the sea.

Antoine de Saint-Exupery

item.title: Why?
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
The world is not perfect. We are all too aware of the problems, but we don't often know where to begin addressing them.
But just because a single one of us may not know what to do, doesn't mean that no one can. Working together we have strength.

item.title: Keep this in mind technology is not the...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Keep this in mind: technology is not the solution. The solution is in us. This is a people problem. We are the ones who are going to make a difference. The technology can only help bring out the best in us. Value: humanism

item.title: Steps 1 Building a community of do gooders...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Steps: 1. Building a community of do gooders. 2. Identifying together what we think are problems. What matters to you? Why? 3. Directing all that energy towards solutions. Let me be honest, only the problem is clear: we don't work together well enough. Not as confident that what's laid out above is necessarily the best way to solve. This will be an ongoing learning process.

item.title: What's your idea Our idea is...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: "What's your idea?" Our idea is that maybe the world could use a little saving! And we're tired of sitting around and waiting for it. Let's be proactive. Let's do this together.

item.title: Issues not ego
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: MTM is more than just personal validation. Keep it about issues. Leave ego at the door.

item.title: Persistent political discourse
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: The conversations on news & social media bubble up around important issues but then lose steam. What if we had a space for conversation that grew over time instead of blowing over?

item.title: "Political"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Political in the sense of polis: the affairs of the community. What matters to us?

item.title: You deserve a place to talk about the...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: You deserve a place to talk about the issues that matter most to you.

item.title: Advice for discussing problems among groups
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Advice for discussing problems among groups from Harvard Business Review: "Conflict Strategies for Nice People"
If you agree that the problem they are trying to solve is important, you will have common ground from which to start sleuthing toward answers.

item.title: Goals
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Maybe This Matters has three primary goals:

1. IDENTIFY issues

What matters to you? What doesn't get appropriate attention in the media? (Why do we hear so much about problems that only affect the rich?) Everyone has the right to voice their concerns. We can answer:
  • Who does this issue effect?
  • Why does it matter? Why may it not matter?
  • What quantitative evidence is there about this issue?
  • What news is there relevant to this issue?

2. CONNECT with others affected

One of our friends was discussing a problem that especially troubles her. She said, "I know I feel this way but I don't know if others care. I don't know how many people out there think about this." We want to end that sentiment. At the end of the day, these are all people problems. We are the ones that created these issues, we are the ones that are continuing to make them worse, and we are the only ones that can do anything about it. Any great achievement has been the result of many people working together. Working together, we can do incredible things. Our value will be in fostering networks around specific issues, we can collaborate to come up with solutions. This offers a network of the most passionate people to easily reach out to for new solutions.

3. COMPILE useful resources and solutions

What's a pressing issue to you? Do you immediately know what you can do to help resolve it? Do others? We're working together to compile links to resources such as charities, volunteer movements, and informational websites (e.g. basics of recycling) so anyone that feels motivated can quickly find the resources they need to make a difference.

item.title: Rant at us
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Looking for a place to vent off steam about all that's wrong about the world? We're ready to hear from you. Make a difference. Reach out.

item.title: Community Building from GOOD
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
While some of us choose social innovation as our profession, I believe it is something that all of us can do no matter what you do and where you are. We can make it a lifestyle. Working towards social change is not only a profession or a skill that you can only learn, it is something that all of us can do in everyday life. Figure out your definition of creating social impact and do it! It can be opting for a project that creates social impact at work or getting more involved with your children's school. Social change cannot be achieved in isolation, let's build a community that chooses social innovation as a lifestyle and let this be the first step you take towards it.
See the original on GOOD: Creative Solutions for Living Well + Doing Good.

item.title: First things first
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Lots of well-intentioned folk know how to fix the world and can offer all sorts of solutions. But proposals require consensus. And often provoke controversy On the other hand, which issues matter to you can't be debated. No one in the world knows what you care about better than you. It's much easier to address a problem once we've agreed that it exists. Why don't we start there?

item.title: Made many updates to the homepage reworked the...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Made many updates to the homepage, reworked the introduction, and added a list of top issues.

item.title: Seth Godin: "Bring us your problems"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Seth Godin writes on his blog today:
"Bring us your problems" We're far more aware of our problems than our opportunities. Our problems nag at us, annoy us and paralyze us. Every organization wrestles with its problems, and is eager to solve them. When you generously invite people to bring you their problems, they might just do that. Solving problems—actually solving them, not just claiming you do—solving perceived, urgent problems, is a surefire way to get the world to beat a path to your door.
Someone should get him to MTM! Original: http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2014/01/bring-us-your-problems.html

item.title: "Issue Tracking for the Real World"
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Two years ago, Ian Gilman wrote about how useful an application like MTM could be:
In this way we create a marketplace of problems and solutions, and we make it easier to shed light on what's needed to fix things. By opening it up to the world, we can encourage people to get involved and take action.
You can read his full post over at his blog: http://blog.iangilman.com/2012/01/issue-tracking-for-real-world.html.

item.title: Contribute to MTM's codebase
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: We're now on GitHub: https://github.com/dsernst/Maybe-This-Matters :)

item.title: Announcing Live Chat
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: A new feature has gone up on MTM: Live Chat. Anytime you want to make the world better, click the blue bar in the bottom right corner to get started. It should work from phones as well. And don't worry even if it says we aren't online. You can still send a message and we'll get back to you ASAP.

item.title: Where we're heading
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: We've been hard at work on the full design and interaction experience for MTM. If you're interested in seeing the direction we're going, have a look at this mockup for an individual Issue page: Thanks for being here :)

item.title: What do people want?
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: A lot of people want to do good. They may want to get into social work, give philanthropy, or join the Peace Corps. What do they want? To give back. To contribute. We want to make the world a better place. MTM's job is to say how the world could be a better place. What are our problems? What could use fixing? What do we want?

item.title: Short domain name
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: New, quicker way to get to MTM: mtm.gs

item.title: First outside funding!
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: I'm very happy to report that MTM has received its first outside funding, for a total of $10! Gotta start somewhere, right? :)

item.title: New Public Changelog
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Are you dying for more details about what's going on with MTM? We're now publishing an index of MTM's User-Visible Improvements on this Twitter: @mtmUVI This is inspired by this fantastic blog post by the goal-setting app Beeminder: "1000 Days of User-Visible Improvements". Check them out.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Three days later, it's clear to say this has made a tremendous difference in the amount of progress made for MTM. See https://www.beeminder.com/mtm/goals/uvi

item.title: MTM Phone Line
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Need to reach MTM on the go? Call or text (615)-5-GET-MTM, that's 615-543-8686. Add it to your contacts. Wherever you go, MTM is by your side (if you have your phone ;) )

item.title: Victory in Cameroon
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Last night was one of the most incredible conversations. This young man in Cameroon found MTM, and immediately connected with our vision. Here are some of the inspiring things he said:
It sounds really interesting I love the part about quality education too those are things that matter to me
I see Americans solving their problems every day And I'm kind of jealous People here don't want to do things They just sit and complain What you're doing here is really cool
I was once working on something about on education too http://globalchallenge.mit.edu/teams/view/473 and I had a very big problem finding people who cared about our mission I've been frustrated with my country so so much that I am willing to anything possible to make it better
Thank you for caring, Arnold. Don't give up!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wow. That's a really interesting problem… How to get the people nearest to the problem to be motivated and involved in helping to solve it. I can imagine there are probably a lot of situations where most of the people involved don't necessarily want to connect to something like MTM, but even having a few connected and acting as liaisons could be worthwhile.

item.title: MTM on Twitter
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: The main MTM Twitter account is @MTM_gs. Follow us! You can also find more detailed changes at @MTMuvi and @MTMinfra for user-visible and under-the-hood improvements, respectively.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This post was used to test new auto-tweeting these updates to @MTM_gs. It worked!

item.title: Victory in Cambridge
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Monday morning brought yet another milestone: the first person to voluntarily use MTM with no prompting or instructions. They just intuitively "got it".
Let's celebrate this as yet another victory in the path towards a world where all feel empowered to speak up about how we can make things better.

item.title: Human progress is neither automatic nor inevitable Every...
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Human progress is neither automatic nor inevitable... Every step toward the goal of justice requires sacrifice, suffering, and struggle; the tireless exertions and passionate concern of dedicated individuals.
<cite>Martin Luther King, Jr.</cite>

item.title: Donations
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Thank you for all the requests to add a donation page! They have been very encouraging :-) Here you go: http://maybethismatters.org/donate/
